channel.title: NYT > New York
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: 7 Children From an Orthodox Jewish Family Die in Brooklyn Fire
item.description: A fire that ripped through the home of an Orthodox Jewish family, trapping the children — ages 5 to 16 — in their bedrooms, was sparked by a malfunctioning hot plate, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NATE SCHWEBER and BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Second Person Dies After Taxi Jumps Curb in the Bronx
item.description: A 5-year-old girl was one of four people struck while they waited for a bus on the Grand Concourse on Friday night, the police said.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: Taxi Jumps Curb, Killing Pedestrian in the Bronx
item.description: One pedestrian was killed and two others critically injured when a taxi jumped a curb along the Grand Concourse in the Bronx on Friday night, the police said.

item.title: A Life Upended After an IV Glucose Treatment Popular Among Asian Immigrants
item.description: Two years since undergoing amputations after receiving a treatment known as a ringer, Myung Hwa Jang has become comfortable with daily routines like climbing into bed and grocery shopping.
item.dc:creator: JIHA HAM
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Myung Hwa Jang at the National Rehabilitation Center in Seoul, South Korea. Ms. Jang's legs were partially amputated after an infection she attributes to a glucose injection.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: See No Junk Food, Buy No Junk Food
item.description: Stores that accept food stamps should give more space to produce.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS A. FARLEY and RUSSELL SYKES

item.title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 20, 2015
item.description: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

item.title: Evicted Tenant Started Queens Fire, Officials Say
item.description: Luis Lopez, 30, was charged with starting a fire that destroyed eight homes on Wednesday night, just minutes after his landlord evicted him, the authorities said.

item.title: Robert Durst’s Papers Are Seized From a Hudson Valley Cellar
item.description: About 60 file boxes belonging to the murder suspect were removed from a friend’s house north of New York City.
item.category: The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst (TV Program)
item.dc:creator: CHARLES V. BAGLI
item.media:credit: Christopher Gregory for The New York Times
item.media:description: Materials belonging to Robert A. Durst were taken from this house in Campbell Hall, N.Y., this week. The house belongs to Susan T. Giordano, who has known Mr. Durst for decades.

item.title: Off-Duty Officer Among 2 Killed in a Wrong-Way Crash on Staten Island
item.description: A car carrying four people, three of whom were off-duty officers in the Linden, N.J., Police Department, collided with a tractor-trailer early Friday morning.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER and JASON GRANT
item.media:description: The destroyed remains of a car involved in a Staten Island crash, where one Linden police officer and a civilian were killed.

item.title: Cuomo Focuses on Ethics Reform, Not on Funding It
item.description: Most of the agencies that concentrate on investigating ethical lapses have seen flat budgets or even cuts, though Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is pushing to increase enforcement.
item.dc:creator: JESSE McKINLEY
item.media:credit: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, at the State Capitol this week, has tied ethics reform to the budget.

item.title: Monir Farmanfarmaian, Iranian and Nonagenarian, Celebrates a New York Museum First
item.description: “Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian: Infinite Possibility. Mirror Works and Drawings 1974-2014” is at the Guggenheim Museum in New York through June 3.
item.dc:creator: RANDY KENNEDY

item.title: Review: The Joyce Unleashed Series, With a Middle Eastern Flavor
item.description: Two works by choreographers with Israeli connections are part of this year’s offsite series by the Joyce Theater.
item.dc:creator: SIOBHAN BURKE
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: , with Netta Yerushalmy performing “Helga and the Three Sailors,” a work she created, at New York Live Arts.

item.title: Crime Scene: Dusting Off a Police Trove of Photographs to Rival Weegee’s
item.description: Thousands of crime scene photographs taken by New York City detectives from 1914 to 1975 will soon be viewed online for the first time ever.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WILSON
item.media:credit: Jake Naughton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Police Department photo from 1959 showing the scene of a stabbing on the Upper West Side.

item.title: Walmart Pays $10 Million to Family of Comedian Killed in Tracy Morgan Crash
item.description: The children of James McNair will split the settlement, which was reached with Walmart in January, months after one of its trucks hit a van carrying Mr. McNair, Mr. Morgan and others on the New Jersey Turnpike.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Denita McNair, 19, and Jamel McNair, 26, the children of James McNair, who was killed in the June 7 crash that injured Tracy Morgan.

item.title: New York City Starts Car Loan Program to Curb Abusive Practices
item.description: After being deluged with complaints, the Department of Consumer Affairs introduces a program for borrowers to get loans directly from some lenders.
item.dc:creator: JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: Julie Menin, the commissioner of New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs.

item.title: City Room: In Winter, Harbor Seals Become New York’s Beach Bums
item.description: The mammals, which are about a human’s size and weight and were once an abundant species in New York harbor but became a rare sight for much of the 20th century, appear to have rebounded.
item.dc:creator: DAVE TAFT
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Harbor seals have become a rare sight for much of the 20th century.

item.title: After a Sleepover With Mayor de Blasio, a Friendship Formed
item.description: Two years after Bill de Blasio slept on their couch, the Wilsons, who have fought for the rights of tenants and the disabled in the city and in Albany, have a personal relationship with the most powerful man in City Hall. The mayor, in turn, has an on-the-ground sounding board.
item.dc:creator: NIKITA STEWART
item.media:credit: Michael Nagle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bill de Blasio spent a night in the apartment of Katherine Wilson in East Harlem in July 2013.

item.title: Spring Is So Close You Can Almost Taste It
item.description: After a winter that has made New Yorkers grateful for a windchill temperature above 15, the hunger for spring has never been so acute and so palpable.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asparagus tartine at Ellary’s Greens, in Greenwich Village.

item.title: Spring Is Due at 6:45 P.M., With Snow
item.description: A storm system expected to bring several inches to New York City on Friday, with the heaviest snowfall during the evening rush, is coinciding with the vernal equinox.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Truckloads of salt arrived on Friday to a storage site on South Street in Lower Manhattan. As many as five inches of snow were forecast for New York City.

item.title: City Room: New York Today: Unbeloved Sculptures
item.description: Friday and the weekend: A final snowy blast, a judge’s refusal in the Eric Garner case, and the week in pictures.
item.dc:creator: ANNIE CORREAL and ANDY NEWMAN
